programme.title: 21st Century War Machines
programme.sub-title: Heavy Metal: Tank vs. Anti Tank
programme.desc: The main battle tank in many ways is the icon of 20th century warfare, but in the 21st century how relevant will it be? How effective will it be? And how much will it cost? The modern battle tank differs vastly from where it started and may in fact be reaching the end of its evolutionary process. Will tanks adapt to survive or be forced to retire from battle?

programme.title: Battlefields
programme.desc: April 16, 1917, for the first time in history, French tanks fight their way through the black sludge of Chemin des Dames. One year before, in October, British tanks tried their luck in Somme. In both cases, the long-awaited miracle did not take place. Yet, a century later, the tanks are still here, monsters of technology that are becoming increasingly efficient.

programme.title: Battlezone: The Gulf War
programme.desc: The ultimate test of tank technology is the battlefield. American tanks form the sharp end of the sword in Desert Storm. The U.S. marine corp was still using the older M-60 tank, although with some modifications.

programme.title: Battlezone: The Korean War
programme.sub-title: Big Picture: United Nations Forces Counterattack
programme.desc: Our allied units throw a powerful counterattack against the Reds, Infantry tanks, artillery, and air all combine to throw the Reds back to the North, The Navy blasts the enemy with rockets. Captain Zimmerman interviews Chaplain Joseph Murphy of Boston, Massachusetts, and Captain John Rock, former company commander with the 1st Cavalry Division in Korea.

programme.title: The Dawns Here Are Quiet
programme.desc: It is late spring of 1942, and World War 2 is in full swing. A long way off from the front-line the Germans make an air landing operation in an attempt to get through to the Kirov railway and the White Sea - Baltic Sea Canal. The only obstacle in their way is an anti-aircraft artillery unit of corporal Vaskov and five young women in training.

programme.title: The Dawns Here Are Quiet
programme.desc: It is late spring of 1942, and World War 2 is in full swing. A long way off from the front-line the Germans make an air landing operation in an attempt to get through to the Kirov railway and the White Sea - Baltic Sea Canal. The only obstacle in their way is an anti-aircraft artillery unit of corporal Vaskov and five young women in training.

programme.title: The Dawns Here Are Quiet
programme.desc: It is late spring of 1942, and World War 2 is in full swing. A long way off from the front-line the Germans make an air landing operation in an attempt to get through to the Kirov railway and the White Sea - Baltic Sea Canal. The only obstacle in their way is an anti-aircraft artillery unit of corporal Vaskov and five young women in training.

programme.title: Heroes Never Die: The Miniseries
programme.desc: With English Closed Captions. A group of Ukrainian Army fighters heads to Donetsk airport for its defense. After being shelled by artillery on the way, a team of four volunteer fighters makes it to the airport to help reinforce. The name Cyborgs, Defenders of the Donetsk Airport, is given to the Ukrainian fighters for their grit, bravery and heroics.

programme.title: Heroes Never Die: The Miniseries
programme.desc: With English Closed Captions. In the New Terminal, the volunteer fighters argue, laugh, violate the commander's orders while defending the airport. The team is given an important task - to hold the first floor of the New Terminal and prepare for the pro-Russian separatist offensive.

programme.title: Heroes Never Die: The Miniseries
programme.desc: With English Closed Captions. Pro-Russian separatists are planning to shell the airport. The night is calm, but in the morning they are attacked with tanks. The fighters repulse the offensive, Injuries and losses mount, However, the defense of the airport is successful and and new group of Ukrainian fighters arrive at the airport to continue the fight.

programme.title: 3 Days in the Life of Lt. Kravtsov
programme.desc: Lt. Kravtsov, a platoon commander, begins his active duty. The odds are against him, as lieutenants typically have only three days to live. Within this time, he must lead his troops in a futile attack, hoping to save the incoming regiment. Can he survive these three days?

programme.title: 3 Days in the Life of Lt. Kravtsov
programme.desc: The weight of unfairness looms over Lt. Kravtsov's fate. The prospect of dying at the tender age of eighteen seems unjust. As he embarks on his mission, the fragility of life and the enormity of his responsibility are inescapable.

programme.title: 3 Days in the Life of Lt. Kravtsov
programme.desc: Lt. Kravtsov's mission demands him to quickly assume command and guide his troops through treacherous circumstances. With limited time, he faces the immense challenge of maintaining morale, making tough decisions, and protecting his men in the face of overwhelming odds.

programme.title: Napoleonic Wars in Russia
programme.desc: In June 1812, Napoleon's 'Grand Army' invaded Russia with over 800,000 soldiers. Despite initial optimism, they faced hardships like hunger and desertion. Alexander I, the Russian Emperor, withdrew from Vilna to engage the enemy. Napoleon hoped for a quick victory, but the Russian strategy was to retreat and draw the invaders deeper into their territory. The French army's discipline waned.

programme.title: Napoleonic Wars in Russia
programme.desc: Napoleon's army advanced toward Moscow in June 1812, eager to defeat Russia's forces and impose peace on their terms. However, the Russians resisted fiercely. The Cossack corps and the Russian vanguard, led by Neverovsky, fought bravely against superior French cavalry. Despite facing overwhelming odds, Neverovsky's men formed a square, defending fiercely, before retreating.

programme.title: Napoleonic Wars in Russia
programme.desc: August 26, 1812. The eve of the bloodiest battle of the Napoleonic Wars in Russia. Two huge armies, quarter million people, clashed near Borodino village, 124 km west of Moscow. Napoleon aimed to seize the village and break through Russian defenses. Bagration's troops bravely fought, but the price was high. Bagration got mortally wounded, but the Russians managed to repel the French attacks.

programme.title: Napoleonic Wars in Russia
programme.desc: Napoleon's army leaves a devastated Moscow after their defeat by the Russian forces. They head towards Maloyaroslavets but are intercepted by the Russian troops led by Kutuzov. Napoleon plans to capture Kaluga for supplies before turning to Smolensk. Russian guerillas and Cossacks provide intelligence, and the Russian army prepares for a decisive battle.

programme.title: Soviet Storm
programme.desc: After the swift success at Smolensk, Hitler has diverted the bulk of Heinz Guderian's panzers down to the South, so as to capture the Ukrainian capital Kiev, considered more important than Moscow in Hitler's mind. It begins a gigantic clash and turns out to be the biggest military encirclement in history.

programme.title: Soviet Storm
programme.desc: Erich von Manstein's soldiers have trapped a massive Soviet force in Crimea, but the doomed troops have no intentions of surrendering, strongly motivated by patriotism. Manstein assembles the greatest concentration of artillery in history, which includes the world's biggest railway-gun nicknamed 'Dora,' and for eight months Soviets troops are savagely bombarded; destroying Sevastopol's only harbor.

programme.title: Soviet Storm
programme.desc: October 1941, Germany's Army Group Center is only some 25 km west of Moscow. The Russian winter, however, is only a few weeks away. With not enough soldiers or military equipment, the Soviet high command's only hope left is that the weather will save the capital. The battle ends in a bloody failure for the German Army, and it is forced to retreat.

programme.title: Soviet Storm
programme.desc: Leningrad, a vital and large Baltic sea port, is facing the entire weight of Army Group North. The Soviets have no reserves to spare as the Battle of Moscow is about to begin. Wilhelm von Leeb's Army Group North fails to take Leningrad, but begins a horrible siege that will last 872 days, in which over a million civilians will die of starvation and disease.

programme.title: Soviet Storm
programme.desc: After the failure to take both Moscow and Leningrad, Hitler sets his sights on the oil fields in the Caucasus. If captured, the Red Army will lose 70-90% of all its oil resources. Therefore, the famous city on the Volga, Stalingrad, must be 'held at all costs.' The German General Staff thinks taking the city will be a matter of a few weeks, but events steadily turn against the Germans.

programme.title: Soviet Storm
programme.desc: Ewald von Kleist has broken through to the Terek river, slap in front of the vital oil fields of Grozny and Baku. Only freezing temperatures in the Caucasus prevent von Kleist's 1st Panzer Army from breaking through to Ozoni Kizi and Tbilisi. The Soviets launch a desperate counter-attack that holds the Germans back.

programme.title: Soviet Storm
programme.desc: After two years of war, Hitler was no closer to victory in the East, and his forces had suffered a devastating defeat at Stalingrad. Now the Germans gathered their strength for one last massive offensive to decide the outcome of the war.

programme.title: Soviet Storm
programme.desc: Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, is, after a lengthy battle, back in Soviet hands. But now they have to clear the Germans and German allies out of the Crimea and liberate the rest of Western Ukraine. Hitler declared the Crimea a 'Festung,' meaning it should be held at all cost and to the last man. The German 17th Army was effectively destroyed in the process.
